title: Lunchtime Concert: The Stone Combo
description: Lunchtime listening: Come along to hear a programme of music by dynamic jazz trio The Stone Combo. This event is free of charge and open to all!

title: Look Club
description: At Look Club we'll be encountering artworks together and will experience art in a way we haven't before. No prior or historical context is necessary and there are no right or wrong answers, only opinions and perspectives. Enjoy this unique session to think deeply and share a space for listening. Come along and meet new people, increase your own sense of confidence and take time to be culturally curious!

title: Glasgow 850 at The Hunterian
venue: Hunterian Art Gallery and Kelvin Hall
description: Glasgow 850 marks Glasgow's 850th anniversary with a year-long programme of events that reflect on how the city has transformed.

title: Re:reading
description: Exhibition exploring libraries as dynamic, collaborative spaces, where fresh insights can by uncovered by re-interpreting collections.

title: Building Memories
description: As part of Glasgow 850, 'Building Memories' looks at three demolished Glasgow buildings, each of which lives on in surprising ways in The Hunterian collections.

title: Geo-Natter
description: Come along to Kelvin Hall on the first Wednesday of each month for Geo-Natter!

title: It Wisnae Us: The Truth About Glasgow and Slavery
description: 'It Wisnae Us' — an exhibition by the Coalition for Racial Equality and Rights (CRER) — is now on display at the Hunterian Museum.

title: Phenomenal Bodies: The Erskine Hospital Archive
venue: Archives & Special Collections foyer, Level 12, University Library
description: This display explores the intertwined history of war, disability, medical innovation and social care in Scotland in the 20th century through archival material from the University of Glasgow. Centred on the pioneering work of Erskine Hospital, it traces the profound impact of technology, institutional care and public narratives of resilience on the experience of disability.

title: Geological Society of Glasgow Lecture Series
description:
Join the Geological Society of Glasgow for a free, public lecture series. The lectures take place on the second Thursday of every month in Kelvin Hall and are open to all to attend!
register now

title: Glasgow 850 – The Evolving City
description: The School of Education warmly invites you to the opening of Glasgow 850: The Evolving City, a photography exhibition celebrating creativity, collaboration, and the evolving built and urban environments of Glasgow. Developed in partnership with Glasgow CREATE & Glasgow schools, the exhibition showcases the work of young photographers who took part in a range of creative workshops. Join us in celebrating these emerging talents and the vibrant partnership between Glasgow's schools and the School of Education.

title: HESPA Autumn 'All-In' Conference
description:
Speaker:
Vivienne Stern (UUK), Chris Hale (University of Otago, Aotearoa New Zealand) and Amanda Oliver (Committee of University Chairs
Free place for the HESPA Autumn 'All-In' Conference – Planners Power Up

speakers.name: Aotearoa New Zealand) and Amanda Oliver (Committee of University Chairs

title: CRADALL seminar: The potential of phenomenography to provide insights into teaching and learning
description:
Speaker:
Gerlese Åkerlind, Professor Emerita, Australian National University
Gerlese will speak about phenomenography and its application, particularly in understanding experiences and learning in HE. This seminar will be of interest to staff across the university with an interest in SoTL, as well as education researchers.

title: RB and Gabriela Cunninghame Graham: International Travel, Domestic Reality
description:
Speaker:
Alan Riach, James Jauncey and others
An illustrated exploration of the works and travels of the great, neglected Scottish writer Robert Bontine Cunninghame Graham (RBCG) and his wife Gabriela, her life and writings. RBCG was one of the foundational figures of the original Labour Party (alongside Keir Hardie) and of the National Party of Scotland in the 1920s, soon to become the SNP in the 1930s. This afternoon explores aspects of the lives and writings of two phenomenal figures in the history of modern Scotland.

title: Carol we now - Glasgow Madrigirls Advent 2025
description: Music & readings for Advent.

title: Byres Community Hub - Hub Monday
category: Open days and visits,  Social events,  Community events
venue: Byres Community Hub, Clarice Pears building
description: Visit Byres Community Hub to see our public spaces, try our interactive exhibits, and meet volunteers, researchers and community groups.

title: Peace in a Changing World: A Fireside Chat with Mark Muller Stuart KC
category: Staff workshops and seminars,  Student events,  Academic events,  Public lectures
venue: Yudowitz Lecture Theatre, Wolfson Medical School
description:
Speaker:
Mark Muller Stuart KC
An engaging dialogue on armed conflicts and peacemaking in the 21st century, presented as a fireside chat with Mark Muller Stuart KC.

title: Advent Carol Service
description: An Anglican carol service for Advent.

title: Approaches to Active Learning: Peer Learning
description:
Speaker:
Dr Aleix Tura Vecino
This session introduces staff to peer learning as a dynamic and inclusive form of active learning. Designed for educators seeking to enhance student engagement and collaboration, the session explores key principles, benefits, and practical applications of peer learning across disciplines.
register now

title: Seminar on Disability and Migration with Dr Rebecca Yeo, from University of Exeter.
category: Community events,  Staff workshops and seminars,  Student events,  Academic events,  Public lectures
venue: Room 734, James McCune Smith with online option
description:
Speaker:
Dr Rebecca Yeo from University of Exeter.
Dr Rebecca Yeo (University of Exeter), author of Disabling Migration Controls, highlights how asylum restrictions actively disable and how insights from the disabled people's movement support justice. The seminar, held on the International Day of Disabled People, explores overlapping injustices in migration, disability, and climate crises. Drawing on the Sensing Climate project and research in Glasgow, the presentation promotes cross-movement collaboration. The project invites Disabled and d/Deaf people with chronic conditions to contribute through conversation or mural ideas. Interpreters and expenses covered.

speakers.name: Dr Rebecca Yeo from University of Exeter.

title: Medical, Veterinary & Life Sciences Postgraduate Open Evening
description: Discover postgraduate taught and research opportunities, explore campus and speak with academic staff at a World Top 50 University for Life Sciences & Medicine. Explore programmes, student insights, support services and postgraduate funding options

title: Lunchtime Concert: Scottish Opera Emerging Artists
description: Lunchtime listening: Scottish Opera's Emerging Artists present a varied programme of works. This event is free and open to all!

title: Views of Glasgow: A Window into Communities
description: Co-curated by members from the Woodlands community, 'Views of Glasgow' combines iconic paintings of the city with objects, artworks and archival material.

title: The 2026 Scottish Election: Housing Evidence Priorities for a New Government
category: Student events,  Academic events,  Public lectures
description:
Speaker:

Join the UK Collaborative Centre for Housing Evidence as we launch our report setting out the cross-cutting housing priorities for the next Scottish Government in 2026
register now

title: The Tlaxcala Codex: Bridging Indigenous worlds and colonial transformations
venue: University of Glasgow Library, Level 2 Exhibition Space
description:
Speaker:
Dr Julia McClure
The University of Glasgow Library presents, "The Tlaxcala Codex: Bridging Indigenous worlds and colonial transformations", a talk by Dr Julia McClure is a senior lecturer in History at University of Glasgow, and a global historian specialising in the histories of poverty, inequality, imperialism, capitalism and the environment (especially focused upon Latin America, the Iberian Peninsula, and the Spanish Empire).

title: Reclaiming Spatial Justice: The Emancipatory Power of Commoning
category: Academic events,  Conferences,  Public lectures,  Staff workshops and seminars
description:
Speaker:
Stavros Stavrides
The seminar will discuss the role of urban commons in producing just urban futures through community action. Prof Stavros Stavrides will be joined by Prof Andy Inch (Urban Studies and Social Policy, University of Glasgow) as the discussant. The seminar will be chaired by Prof David Featherstone (Human Geography Research Group, University of Glasgow), and is co-organised with the recently launched research network Just City by the Med.

title: Twilight Tour: Glasgow Coins and Medals
description:
Speaker:
Jesper Ericsson
Join Hunterian Curator of Numismatics, Jesper Ericsson for a behind-the-scenes session exploring Glasgow coins and medals from The Hunterian collections.
book your place

Professor Naveed Sattar
This year's School of Health & Wellbeing Christmas lecture will be given by Naveed Sattar, Professor of Metabolic Medicine at the University of Glasgow: "Obesity and weight loss drugs: why all the fuss?"

title: UofG London Burns Supper
description: Join us for a celebration of Scottish culture and heritage at our London Burns Supper, with a night of great entertainment, whisky and food!

title: UofG Glasgow Burns Supper
description: Join the University of Glasgow as they host a Glasgow Burns Supper in the Bute Hall on the Gilmorehill campus! This event offers alumni, friends and students the opportunity to celebrate the life, works and spirit of the great Scottish poet, Robert Burns, in a night that highlights and embraces Scottish culture and heritage.

category: Staff workshops and seminars,  Academic events

title: SoTL Network The Stations of SoTL: Design
description:
Speaker:
Dr Nathalie Tasler, Dr Linnea Soler and Dr Sarah Honeychurch
We begin the new year by looking at how best to design a SoTL project. Whether we are contemplating embarking on a literature review, designing a learning and teaching intervention or undertaking an evaluation of a previous intervention, it is vital to spend time planning at the outset. In this session we will consider the main methodologies that we might use for a SoTL project, and the methods associated with each.
register now

speakers.name: Dr Linnea Soler and Dr Sarah Honeychurch

category: Staff workshops and seminars,  Public lectures,  Academic events,  Student events
description:
Speaker:
Dr Francesco Della Puppa (Ca' Foscari University of Venice); Dr Giuliana Sanò (University of Messina); Dr Giulia Storato (University of Padua); Dr Chi
Identities Special Issue Panel Event in collaboration with University of Glasgow Social Anthropology & Migration. 

This event draws on a Special Issue published by Identities: Global Studies in Culture and Power: Investigating Social Change: 'Migratory Stratifications' as a Fresh Analytical Tool, Vol 32 No 6.

Dr Sim Innes - Gaelic song poetry and British Empire conflicts 1874-1930.

title: Applying for the SoTL Funding Scheme
description:
Speaker:
Dr Sarah Honeychurch and Dr Nathalie Tasler
This session is aimed at colleagues who would like to know more about the SoTL Funding Scheme and are interested in applying. We will look through the call for bids for 2025-26 and consider which types of project might be eligible. Members of the network who have been successful in their bids will be available to talk about their projects and offer advice.
register now

speakers.name: Dr Sarah Honeychurch and Dr Nathalie Tasler

title: From Design to Dialogue: Building Feedback Literacy for Staff and Students
description:
Speaker:
Dr Kimberly Davis
This session will equip participants with the knowledge, strategies, and tools to enhance their own feedback literacy and to foster feedback literacy in their students. It emphasizes feedback as a dialogic, developmental process embedded in assessment design and everyday teaching practice.
register now

title: SoTL Network The Stations of SoTL: Investigate
description:
Speaker:
Dr Nathalie Tasler, Dr Linnea Soler and Dr Sarah Honeychurch
The focus of our SoTL journey this month is investigation. Once we have identified a possible SoTL project and decided on a project design, how do we begin our investigation? In this session we ask questions about how to establish which resources we might need, how much time we have to dedicate to our project and who else might be available to support us.
register now

speakers.name: Dr Linnea Soler and Dr Sarah Honeychurch

title: Scottish Ensemble: Between Light and Shadow
description: Join a quartet of Scottish Ensemble musicians for a performance of emotional contrasts, bold imagination, and luminous soundscapes.

title: From Silos to Synergy: Supporting Student Learning Through a Programme Focused Approach to Assessment and Feedback
description:
Speaker:
Dr Kimberly Davis
Programmatic assessment implies that assessment is organised across a programme, rather than for individual courses. This programme structure allows for iterative assessment practices to flourish, and for students to engage with the assessment process more meaningfully. This session will help participants think about how to map their courses programmatically and make meaningful links between courses on a programme.
register now

title: People & Excellence 2026: Celebrating Achievements in Knowledge Exchange & Innovation
category: Academic events,  Exhibitions,  Public lectures,  Social events,  Student events
description: Celebration of staff and students delivering meaningful engagement, innovation and impact. Awards presentations.

title: SoTL Network The Stations of SoTL: Write
description:
Speaker:
Dr Nathalie Tasler, Dr Linnea Soler and Dr Sarah Honeychurch
The focus of this month's stage of the SoTL journey is writing. Of course, this is an activity that occurs throughout the whole process, from reflection all the way through to implementation. In this session we look at how to identify ways in which to build in writing into your regular practices, whether those be daily, weekly, or less often. As well as looking at strategies for developing regular writing practices, we will also consider which tools you might use to help you to take and make notes.
register now

speakers.name: Dr Linnea Soler and Dr Sarah Honeychurch

title: SoTL Network The Stations of SoTL: Disseminate
description:
Speaker:
Dr Nathalie Tasler, Dr Linnea Soler and Dr Sarah Honeychurch
This month we consider how to develop a dissemination strategy for SoTL practitioners. We will begin with a series of questions which are designed to help us to build our personal plan for dissemination before looking at some of the pathways for publication which are available for UofG colleagues internally and externally. Examples of successful SoTL publications will be provided in order to help us to plan for our own publications.
register now

speakers.name: Dr Linnea Soler and Dr Sarah Honeychurch

title: SoTL Network The Stations of SoTL: Reflect
description:
Speaker:
Dr Nathalie Tasler, Dr Linnea Soler and Dr Sarah Honeychurch
We end our SoTL journey this year as we began, with reflection. In this session we each take time to look back at our previous learning, teaching and SoTL activities and celebrate any successes we have had, however large or small these might be. We also reflect on any challenges we have faced and consider how we might overcome any such barriers in the future. Then we look forward and consider how we would like to engage in SoTL over the summer months – and even begin planning for the next academic year.
register now

speakers.name: Dr Linnea Soler and Dr Sarah Honeychurch
